title: Waialeale (steamboat)
text:
The Hawaiian schooner Waialeale (pronounced Wye-Ally-Ally) operated in the early 1900s as part of the <a href="Puget%20Sound%20Mosquito%20Fleet">Puget Sound Mosquito Fleet</a>. She was known colloquially as "Weary Willy".
Construction & Operations.
"Waialeale" was built in 1884 by the Hall Brothers at <a href="Port%20Blakely%2C%20Bainbridge%20Island%2C%20Washington">Port Blakely</a>. In 1905 the vessel was brought to <a href="Puget%20Sound">Puget Sound</a> by Cary Cook of Cook & Company and operated as a propeller steamer on the <a href="Tacoma">Tacoma</a>-<a href="Vancouver%20B.C.">Vancouver</a> run, replacing the "<a href="Mainlander%20%28steamboat%29">Mainlander</a>". In 1907 she was taken over by the <a href="Puget%20Sound%20Navigation%20Company">Puget Sound Navigation Company</a>. She was dismantled in <a href="Seattle">Seattle</a> in 1927.
